Name: vehicle_sales
Description: vehicle_sales table derived from Excel data dictionary

Columns.Name: id(PK)
Columns.Comment: Unique identifier for each vehicle sale record.

Parameters.usage: A system-generated primary key that uniquely identifies each transaction. It ensures data integrity and is used for joining with other tables. No two records share the same ID.

Columns.Name: location_id
Columns.Comment: Identifier for the location where the sale occurred.

Parameters.usage: Represents the dealership or branch where the sale was made. Useful for regional performance analysis and mapping. Can be linked to a location metadata table.

Columns.Name: date_added
Columns.Comment: Date the sale record was added.

Parameters.usage: Indicates when the record was entered into the system. Useful for tracking data entry timelines and system updates. May differ from actual deal date.
A unique alphanumeric code assigned to each customer. Helps in tracking customer history and repeat purchases. Can be used for customer segmentation.
Contains the first name of the customer. Only one unique value suggests placeholder or anonymized data. Not reliable for personalization or analysis.
Stores the middle name of the customer. Like first name, low uniqueness implies missing or defaulted values. Often unused in analysis.
Customer’s surname or family name. Uniform value across records suggests anonymization. Not suitable for identity verification.
First line of the customer’s residential or mailing address. Useful for geocoding and demographic profiling. Often includes street name and number.
Optional second line of address, such as apartment or suite number. Enhances location precision. May be blank for many records.
Specifies the city where the customer resides. Useful for regional analysis and clustering. Can be used with state and zip for full location.
Indicates the state or province of the customer’s residence. Helps in grouping by administrative regions. Often used in compliance and reporting.

Columns.Name: zip
Columns.Comment: Postal code of the customer's address.

Parameters.usage: Represents the postal or ZIP code for the customer’s location. Useful for geospatial mapping and delivery logistics. Can be used to infer income or population density.
No unique values suggest this field is either masked or not collected. Typically used for contact verification. May be deprecated.
Similar to home phone, this field is empty or anonymized. Historically used for daytime contact. Not useful in current dataset.
Mobile contact number of the customer. Zero uniqueness implies masking or non-collection. Often used for SMS or app notifications.
Primary digital contact for the customer. High uniqueness indicates good data quality. Useful for marketing, communication, and identity verification.

Columns.Name: b_email
Columns.Comment: Indicates if customer opted in for email communication.

Parameters.usage: Binary or flag field showing email consent. Helps in filtering customers for campaigns. May follow GDPR or similar compliance rules.

Columns.Name: b_phone
Columns.Comment: Indicates if customer opted in for phone communication.

Parameters.usage: Shows whether the customer agreed to receive phone calls. Zero uniqueness suggests missing or default values. Important for telemarketing compliance.

Columns.Name: b_mail
Columns.Comment: Indicates if customer opted in for mail communication.

Parameters.usage: Indicates consent for receiving physical mail. Often used for direct mail campaigns. Zero uniqueness may imply default opt-out.

Columns.Name: deal_number
Columns.Comment: Unique identifier for the vehicle deal.

Parameters.usage: Transaction-specific identifier used to track the deal. Can be used to join with financing or inventory records. May be reused across systems.
Represents the actual date of sale or contract signing. Crucial for revenue recognition and trend analysis. May differ from stock or entry date.
Globally unique identifier for each vehicle. Used for tracking, insurance, and registration. Essential for vehicle history and fraud prevention.

Columns.Name: stock_no
Columns.Comment: Internal stock number for the vehicle.

Parameters.usage: Dealership-assigned inventory number. Helps in managing vehicle stock and availability. May not be unique across locations.
Indicates the model year of the vehicle. Useful for depreciation, valuation, and lifecycle analysis. Often used in filtering and grouping.
Brand or company that produced the vehicle (e.g., Toyota, Ford). Key for brand-level analysis and market share studies. Often paired with model and year.
Specific model name of the vehicle (e.g., Civic, Corolla). Used for detailed vehicle classification. Important for pricing and inventory decisions.
Shows how much the vehicle has been driven. Critical for valuation and wear analysis. May influence financing and warranty terms.
Date when the vehicle was added to dealership inventory. Useful for aging and turnover analysis. May precede deal date significantly.
Amount paid by the dealership to acquire the vehicle. Used for margin and profitability calculations. May include transportation or prep fees.
Unique ID for the salesperson handling the deal. Useful for performance tracking and commission calculation. Can be linked to HR systems.
Full name of the salesperson. Used for reporting and recognition. May be duplicated across locations or teams.

Columns.Name: deal_type_id
Columns.Comment: Identifier for the type of deal.

Parameters.usage: Categorical field representing deal structure (e.g., lease, cash, finance). Important for financial modeling and customer segmentation. Can be mapped to descriptive labels.

Columns.Name: purchase_price
Columns.Comment: Final purchase price of the vehicle.

Parameters.usage: Total amount paid by the customer. Includes vehicle cost, fees, and taxes. Used for revenue and margin analysis.
Name of the financial institution providing the loan. Useful for lender performance and partnership analysis. May be null for cash deals.
Annual percentage rate applied to the loan. Influences monthly payment and total cost. Important for affordability and risk modeling.
Duration of the loan agreement. Common terms include 36, 48, or 60 months. Used to calculate amortization and payment schedules.
Amount the customer pays each month. Derived from rate, term, and purchase price. Key metric for affordability and credit analysis.
Identification number of the vehicle traded in by the customer. Useful for inventory replenishment and valuation. May be null if no trade-in.
Indicates current state of the deal (e.g., active, cancelled). Used for workflow and reporting. Can be mapped to status labels.
Binary indicator for excluding records from reporting or modeling. Often used for test data or incomplete entries. Helps maintain data quality.

Columns.Name: latitude
Columns.Comment: Geographic latitude of the sale location.

Parameters.usage: Precise north-south coordinate of the sale. Enables geospatial mapping and clustering. Often paired with longitude.

Columns.Name: longitude
Columns.Comment: Geographic longitude of the sale location.

Parameters.usage: East-west coordinate of the sale location. Used for mapping and regional analysis. Can be visualized on GIS platforms.
Numeric score indicating accuracy of geolocation. Higher values suggest better precision. Useful for filtering unreliable coordinates.
Raw string combining year, make, and model. May be used for parsing or standardization. Helps in matching with external vehicle databases.

Columns.Name: data_style_id
Columns.Comment: Identifier for data style or format.

Parameters.usage: Represents the format or template used during data entry. Useful for source tracking and normalization. May vary by system or vendor.

relationships.description: Vehicle sales are matched with inventory records via location ID.
